child.geography: Aramkea, Aranim, Bak, Bakana, Betiana, Daburaba, Disana, Divana, Divana-Siremti, Divana-Woitapa, Duban, Gaututian, Gautagan, Iua, Kasanbak, Kunana, Kusana, Kusdoban, Kweptana, Lindana, Menma, Nianong, Sanaptiamin, Sembati, Tavea, Teka, Teranmin, Tomiana, Waula, Yendana, Duranmin Emiapmin, Kamagoiana, Khakna, Kutik, Suarmin
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: Population: 6700? (1970 estimate). Laycock writes that there has been general grammatical sketches done of this language, but no basic vocabulary has been published. He also notes that some villages may be Hewa or Bimin speaking, though he does not suggest which. (Laycock 1973: 51)

child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: "The language of Oksapmin has previously been regarded as an isolate…however, in recent publications by Wurm (1972, 1973) it is tentatively included in the Trans-New Guinea Phylum as a stock-level isolate. Further research may however show that it is more closely related to a Sepik isolate such as Yuri." (Laycock 1973: 51)

child.geography: Gadio, Towi, Bisorio, Iniai
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: Population: 200? (1970 estimate). "The language has been known by each of its village names, and shows close relationships with the language called Nere (Nete, Neta) to the south…Bisorio may also be the same language as Lemben, reported as a northern Enga dialect/language." (Laycock 1973: 51)

child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: "In recent years, a few speakers of languages of this stock/family have ben moving down from the mountains into the Sepik area. Data is conflicting on how many languages are involved, but collation of all information suggests that there is only one language, with perhaps a number of distinct dialects." (Laycock 1973: 50-51)

child.pri-name: Central and South New Guinea Stock

child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: Population: 680 (1970). "Most of the villages are newly-censused…The border between Wagarabai and Mianmin is also not established; the two languages in any case resemble each other closely. The population estimate is based on the populations of the above-listed villages, all of which were censused in 1970, but is not likely to include all Wagarabai speakers." (Laycock 1973: 50)

child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 3329 (1970 estimate).

child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: Population: 1500 (1970 estimate). Laycock notes that some of the villages where Mianmin is spoken may also be Wagarabai speaking, however, he does not suggest which ones. (Laycock 1973: 50)

Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: "Languages of the Central and South New Guinea Stock are represented in the Sepik region only by members of the Ok Family, for which the principle documentation is Healey (1964). More data on the whole group can be found in Voorhoeve (1968), and McElhanon and Voorhoeve (1970).

child.geography: Mongo, Pananggau, Tengirabu, Terauwi, Akrani, Amandan, Bibriari, Fisi, Kwaramun, Merewe, Nai No.1, Purumun, Senagi, Unupai, Wamu, Samanai
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: Population: 2565 (1970). Laycock writes that several scholars (e.g. S. Literal (1972)) have noted that approximately 10% of the vocabulary of Anngor corresponds to that of Ndu languages. Laycock argues, however, that these correlations are likely the result of borrowing. (Laycock 1973: 49)

child.geography: Monggowar (and other villages?)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: Population: 230 (1970). See Voorhoeve (1971) and Galis (1956) for more information. (Laycock 1973: 49)

child.geography: Akimari, Kamberatoro, Lihen, Mamambra, Mangwar, Menggau, Mongrovei, Nindebai, Orkwanda, Tamarbek, Yamamainda, Amgotro, Komanda, Menggwari, Yiforo (West Irian)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: Population: 1474 (1970). See Loving and Bass (1964) and Voorhoeve (1971) for more information. (Laycock 1973: 49)

child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: "The Senagi stock-level family was first postulated by Loving and Bass (1964), though they did not appear to recognize the relationship of languages in it to those of the Waris Family. The language of Duka-Ekor is added from Voorhoeve (1971). The name Anggor is now being used by SIL writers in preference to Senagi, as the name of one of the member languages, but Senagi is retained for the stock of the family." (Laycock 1973: 48)

child.geography: Simog, Watape
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: Population: 270 (1970). See Loving and Bass (1964) for more information.

child.geography: Bambol, Aheri, Akraminag, Aurump, Bahariag, Bipan, Einokneri, Iafar No.1, Iafar No.2, Iafar No.3, Ibagum, Ifigeri, Iframinag, Ivieg, Kabaineri, Kwofinau, Masineri, Mouri, Muwaineri, Nai No.2, Naineri, Mambaineri, Oweniak, Petaineri No.1, Petaineri No.2, Seraminag, Waineri, Wamaru, Wofneri, Wogineri, Yumor No.1, Yumor No.2, Yuwero
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: Population: 3354 (1970). See Loving and Bass (1964) for more information. (Laycock 1973: 47)

child.geography: Ampas, Kok, Komieti, Major, Mingk, Oum, Pendesi, Sach, Senck, Swach (West Irian), Dauchendi, Daundi, Doponendi, Epmi, Imonda, Kolosa, Machendi, Mindepoke, Namola, Omol, Sainendi, Swach-Ketjil, Tokonendi, Wainda, Yuwetla
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: Population: 3160 (1970 estimate). Laycock notes that the dialect of Waris spoken in the village of Imonda is very distinct, and even regarded as a separate language by Imonda villagers. (Laycock 1973: 46)

child.geography: Jeti, Kibae, Kriku, Skofro, Skotiaho, Uskwar, Wembi (West Irian)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: Population: 400 (1970 estimate). Laycock notes that the villages of Ampas, Komieti and Major are bilingual Waris/Manem speakers. (Laycock 1973: 46)

child.geography: Daonda
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: Population: 135 (1970). Laycock writes that many forms of this language are close to the Imonda dialect of Waris. (Laycock 1973: 47)

child.geography: Senggi, Tomfor, Umbekwai (West Irian)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: Population: 120 (1970 estimate). See Voorhoeve (1970) and Galis (1956) for more information. (Laycock 1973: 46)

child.geography: Arombawai, Ibela, Jabae, Jabanda, Makrabo (West Irian), Punda, Sowanda No.1, Sowanda No.2, Umeda, Waina, Wiala
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
child.pub-comments: Population: 1100 (1970 estimate). "Listed as Sowanda by Loving and Bass (1964), and as Waina by Voorhoeve (1970); it is unclear whether two languages are involved, or only one. If there are two languages, then Waina would appear to be an inappropriate name for the language spoken in West Irian, as the village of Waina is on the Australian [note- Papua New Guinea was not yet independent at the time of the book's publishing] side of the border." (Laycock 1973: 47)

child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 800 (1961 estimate). See Voorhoeve (1970) for more information. (Laycock 1973: 48)

child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Laycock writes that the name 'Border Stock' reflects a group of languages spoken on the border of Papua New Guinea and West Irian (Indonesia). He notes that linguistically, the languages show strong resemblances to Trans-New Guinean languages, but also to the Sepik-Ramu phylum. (Laycock 1973: 46)

root.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
root.pub-comments: "The history of the Trans-New Guinea phylum is almost the history of linguistic classification in New Guinea, and cannot be dealt with in detail here. It was first proposed as the New Guinea Macrophylum (in, e.g. Wurm (1970), and further documented by McElhanon and Voorhoeve (1970)). the number of languages included in it now totals 422 (Wurm 1970), making by far the largest single group of language in Papua New Guinea and West Irian. The size of the group makes it impossible to deal with it in this paper, which is primarily concerned with the Sepik region; accordingly, only those languages and families are discussed which occur in the Sepik Region, and/or in which the author has additional data." (Laycock 1973: 45)
